title: Where did Christopher Columbus' ships land? - Quora

response.answer_text: They never landed in what became the United States. They first reached land in the Bahamas at Samaná Cay. Columbus (Christopher Colon) landed here after sailing 3,200 miles in slightly over 33 days. His route was used for nearly 400 years and is still used by yachtsman. Columbus's route was called, “The Ladies Run” and instructions for sailing from northern Europe were “South until the butter melts, then west”. No literate person in 1492 believed the world was flat. In the third century B.C. (3,000 years before Christ), the Greek astronomer Eratosthenes, using only his brain and a shadow-casting column, came astonishing close to the circumference.

He first landed in Bimini island and named it San Salvador. Then he went south and anchored near Cuba and named it Juana. He didn't step foot on the island but sent a crew by boat who didn't see anybody but tabacco plants. Finally he landed in what is now Haiti and named it Hispañola in honor of Queen Elizabeth. After landing, the Santa Maria ship crashed against the rocks during a storm on 24 December and built a fort with the wood of the ship which he named Navidad.

The Bahamas were the first islands he encountered. You can see there are many, many, places where he landed. The Bahamas were only a stepping stone. Heres a list of the most significant places he landed: Hispaniola, Cuba, Lesser Antilles, Jamaica and probably many others I'm forgetting. Here's a simple map to show his journeys chronologically.  Edit: If you're interested, here’s a translation of a long and well detailed journal from his initial voyage, albeit exhaustive nonetheless. http://www.americanjourneys.org/pdf/AJ-062.pdf

From the web. On the explorer's first voyage to the New World in 1492, Christopher Columbus and his crew landed at an island called Guanahani by the locals and named San Salvador by Columbus. It was located in the Bahamas, but Guanahani's modern counterpart is still unknown and disputed.

The first landfall was in the Bahamas, and Columbus called the island San Salvador. There is an island of that name in the Bahamas today - though there is some uncertainty as to whether that is the actual island where Columbus first landed. Samana Cay has been suggested as better fitting the description given.

There is a very strong argument that Columbus first landed on the north end of the island of Eleuthra in the Bahamas. This is called the Northern Route. Arne Molander compiled facts over thirty years to make this case and to dispute other locations based on Columbus’ log entries. Check out Egg Island Landfall if you are interested in reading more.
